data.question: What technique was used to probe the Fe-O/OH vibrations in FeIII-hydroxido and FeIV/III-oxido complexes?
data.answer: 57Fe nuclear resonance vibrational spectroscopy (NRVS)

data.question: What effect do intramolecular hydrogen bonds have on the vibrational properties of monomeric Fe@O(H) complexes?
data.answer: Intramolecular hydrogen bonds affect the vibrational frequencies of Fe@O(H) units, with changes in the hydrogen bonding networks resulting in significant changes in their vibrational frequencies.

data.question: True or False: The primary coordination sphere ligands and their geometry do not influence the metal redox potentials for substrate reactivity.
data.answer: False

data.question: What is the primary goal of altering the ligand structure in synthetic systems for dioxygen binding and activation?
data.answer: To systematically correlate changes between the primary coordination sphere and hydrogen-bonding networks within the secondary coordination sphere of metal centers.

data.question: How does the NRVS technique compare to other vibrational spectroscopies in studying iron centers?
data.answer: NRVS has high specificity and sensitivity to the iron centers because it detects all vibrational modes with iron motion.

data.question: True or False: The FeIII-hydroxido and FeIV/III-oxido complexes used in the study have identical secondary coordination spheres.
data.answer: False

data.question: What was the observed effect of protonation of the oxido ligand in FeIII-oxido complexes?
data.answer: Protonation caused a significant red shift in the energy of the Fe@O vibration, indicating changes in the Fe-O bond character.

data.question: True or False: The Fe@O(H) bond length and its stretching frequency have no correlation.
data.answer: False

data.question: What does the correlation between Fe@O(H) bond length and stretching frequency demonstrate?
data.answer: It demonstrates the utility of NRVS in studying the effect of the secondary coordination sphere to the reactivities of iron complexes.

data.question: True or False: The study found that hydrogen bonding interactions in FeIII-hydroxido complexes do not affect chemical transformations.
data.answer: False

data.question: What was the impact of a single hydrogen bond on the FeIII@OH bond?
data.answer: A single hydrogen bond affected the strength of the FeIII@OH bond, with a stronger hydrogen bond correlating with a higher Fe@O vibrational frequency.

data.question: True or False: The NRVS spectra of FeIII-hydroxido and FeIV/III-oxido complexes were identical across all samples.
data.answer: False

data.question: What was the role of DFT calculations in the study?
data.answer: DFT calculations provided support for spectral assignments and helped in understanding the structural and vibrational properties of the complexes.

data.question: True or False: The study exclusively focused on the primary coordination sphere of metal complexes.
data.answer: False

data.question: How did the study contribute to understanding the reactivity of FeIV-oxido intermediates?
data.answer: It provided quantitative measurements of the modulation of Fe@O bonding and insights into the stability of O@H bonds in FeIII@OH species, which can be used to model the reactivity of complexes involving FeIV-oxido units.

data.question: True or False: The study demonstrated that NRVS is insensitive to changes in the secondary coordination sphere.
data.answer: False

data.question: What was the significance of using isotopically labeled complexes in the study?
data.answer: Isotopically labeled complexes helped in confirming the origin of specific vibrational features, particularly in distinguishing between Fe@O and Fe@OH vibrations.

data.question: True or False: The study suggests that the secondary coordination sphere does not influence the chemical properties of metalloenzymes.
data.answer: False

data.question: What was the effect of changing the cavity architecture in FeIII-oxido complexes?
data.answer: Changing the cavity architecture to include a lone hydrogen bond acceptor partially restored the Fe-oxido bond character, affecting the Fe-O(H) vibration energies.

data.question: True or False: The study found that all ligands provide a different electronic environment to the Fe center.
data.answer: False
